I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will identify, demonstrate, and 
evaluate  how  to  use  high-level  technologies  to  effectively  plan  high-quality  infrastructure 
investments, especially for transport infrastructure, and measure their economic impacts.1 The 
TA team will share and discuss lessons from the TA with developing member countries (DMCs) 
and Asian Development Bank (ADB) operations departments for planned or future ADB projects 
and government policies in developing Asia, including upper middle-income countries. 
 
2.  The proposed TA aligns with operational priority 2 of ADB’s Strategy 2030, accelerating 
progress in gender equality; operational priority 4, making cities more livable; operational priority 
5,  promoting  rural  development  and  food  security;  operational  priority  6,  strengthening 
governance and institutional capacity; and operational priority 7, fostering regional cooperation 
and integration.2 In addition, it aligns with the Group of Twenty (G20) Principles for Quality 
Infrastructure investment, adopted at the 2019 G20 Osaka Summit.3 The TA is included in the 
2021 annual work program of ADB’s Economic Research and Regional Cooperation Department 
(ERCD).4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Since the start of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, big data (including 
images generated through satellite data) has proven useful in helping governments understand 
the effectiveness of various COVID-19 control measures. For example, mobile phone data have 
been used to track the extent of people’s movements in response to quarantines or other 
restrictions on travel within and across cities. Expanded and deepened use of big data and 
satellite images has stimulated the demand for big data analysis for other objectives, including 
public agencies’ management of infrastructure. Planning investments in infrastructure is complex, 
requiring an understanding of how different types of investments interact with one another, 
existing regulations and economic conditions, and the behavior of economic agents (e.g., firms 
and workers). Similarly, monitoring the quality of infrastructure is costly.  
 
4.  Fortunately, recent advancement in high-level technology offers opportunities to better 
plan, construct, and maintain high-quality infrastructure.5 Spatial information, artificial intelligence, 
machine learning, and the Internet of Things could be used for planning, designing, constructing, 
maintaining, and monitoring high-quality infrastructure projects. For example, satellite imagery 
analysis is a type of geo-coded big data that enables monitoring of the quality and usage of 
transport infrastructure. Machine learning algorithms can be developed to extract features of high-
resolution satellite imagery which correlate with available data on infrastructure quality, and 
subsequently apply those algorithms to predict infrastructure quality outside of study areas. 
Similarly, information from telecommunication companies can be used to infer how location and 
travel decisions of economic agents respond to different types and qualities of infrastructure. 
 
 
1  The concept of high-quality infrastructure covers not only physical condition, functionality, and regulations on the use 
of infrastructure, but also climate and disaster resilience. Knowledge products to be prepared under the TA will reflect 
insights on these topics, to the extent possible. 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  G20. 2019. G20 Principles for Quality Infrastructure Investment. Annex Paper 1 to the G20 Osaka Leaders’ 
Declaration, G20 Summit. Osaka. 28–29 June. 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 16 July 2020. 
5  In addition, big data and analysis could be used for selecting project proposals via optimization and contextualization. 
ADB, Asian Development Blog. 2019. Can big data help us make better development decisions?

2 
5.  DMC governments, however, have difficulty with identifying appropriate and feasible high-
level technology options and have limited capacity to use them. Without proper planning, valuable 
opportunities could be missed. Big data generated from the high frequency data collection could 
remain idle, compromised, or even lost or intentionally deleted to reduce data storage costs.6 
Thus, there is a strong and urgent need to conduct pilot and case studies of effective use of high-
level technologies to draw policy recommendations. 
 
6.  ADB’s support for infrastructure takes different forms and provides an excellent basis for 
choosing an appropriate and useful set of pilot and case studies to consider. One example 
concerns the provision of urban transport infrastructure. Because cities are the locus of structural 
transformation and economic development—i.e., where more productive and innovative firms, 
better-paying jobs, and key institutions and amenities are located—developing Asia’s ongoing 
urbanization process should be good news for the region’s growth prospects. 7 However, Asia’s 
expanding cities, which account for a growing share of total population, will not automatically reap 
the benefits of urban growth. Efficient provision and sound management of urban transport 
infrastructure, alongside appropriate land use planning systems and other infrastructure, play a 
key role in maximizing the benefits of urban agglomeration. As investments in urban infrastructure 
grow in the region, it is necessary to understand how they help improve urban mobility and 
amenities and thus contribute to economic growth. Studies on these issues are quite limited 
(largely because of weakness associated with traditional data sources), and capacity to efficiently 
regulate  and  manage  public  utilities  (such  as  water  supply  and  sewage,  energy, 
telecommunication) remains weak in developing Asia. Rigorous research, made possible by 
emerging geo-coded big data, could help fill knowledge gaps and support informed policy making. 
To create livable cities, city governments in the region could also learn from successful experience 
in managing and regulating utilities to deliver better service. 
 
7.  Another aspect of ADB’s support for infrastructure is a regional approach, the first example 
being the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) program, established with ADB support in 1992.8 
The GMS covers six countries along the Mekong River across 2.6 million square kilometers. Since 
1992, ADB provided more than $8 billion in financing to support priority GMS projects. A large 
share of the GMS investment programs is concentrated on building roads, bridges, and other 
infrastructure to forge mutually beneficial links and drive growth. Although some studies have tried 
to quantify the impacts of the GMS infrastructure investments for the region, the studies suffer 
from lack of reliable national and regional data and are of varying quality and coverage. Recent 
development in spatial information technology, such as satellite imagery analysis, provides an 
opportunity to measure the benefits across countries’ borders, because such data  are not 
constrained by national boundaries and provide granular and consistent information across all 
relevant geographical units. 
 
 
6  Examples of high-frequency data include real-time night and daytime satellite imagery; container shipments, air 
freight, and other granular flight data; mobile phone records and crowd-sourced internet data evaluated through 
artificial intelligence technologies; local carbon dioxide readings, wind speed, rainfall, and electric power absorption 
from national grid data; real time traffic data from roadway sensors and live operations centers; and consumer 
transaction data. 
7  According to the United Nation’s World Urbanization Prospects data, the number of urban inhabitants in developing 
Asia increased from 375 million to 1.8 billion between 1970 and 2017, accounting for 53% of the global increase in 
urban population. Current models suggest that from 2017 to 2050, the number of urban inhabitants is projected to 
increase by almost 70% from 1.8 billion to 3 billion. This implies an increase in the urbanization rate from 46% to 
64% between 2017 and 2050. 
8  Subsequently, ADB started supporting the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program in 1997 and the 
South Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program in 2001.

3 
8.  At the national level, ADB is increasing its support to rural road connectivity. For instance, 
ADB’s Integrated Road Investment Program, tranche 1, for Sri Lanka rolled out interventions in 
five provinces and one rural district.9 The program’s second, third, and fourth tranches were 
approved to cover rural road constructions in other remaining provinces. The program roads are 
scattered across large areas, and it is difficult to monitor the investment projects and evaluate the 
impacts. The evaluation needs to identify hundreds of road sections and comparable road 
sections that are outside of the project. For the study, international experts propose the use of 
call detail record of mobile phones, subject to data availability, to monitor traffic movements.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcomes 
 
9.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: Physical and financial sustainability of 
transportation infrastructure in ADB DMCs improved.10 The TA will have the following outcomes: 
Transportation infrastructure monitoring and maintenance systems in ADB DMCs improved and 
operation and maintenance costs reduced.11 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
10.  Output 1: Pre-feasibility study on the use of innovative technologies and data 
sources for enhanced monitoring of infrastructure quality conducted. The TA will use 
representative data on transport infrastructure quality collected through innovative technologies 
(e.g., laser trackers on vehicles, accelerometers or gyroscopes installed on mobile phones, or 
crowd-sourced internet data). It will fine-tune existing algorithms that have been pre-trained on 
traditional satellite imagery or other types of innovative data and use transfer learning techniques 
so they can expedite the algorithm’s learning rate to predict infrastructure quality in multiple 
settings. Following recently developed techniques, the TA team and consultants will craft learning 
algorithms to predict poverty and other development indicators to assess the impact of quality 
transport infrastructure on communities. The TA team will arrange training programs for relevant 
government agency officers on these algorithms.12 Overall, this component of the TA will serve 
as a pre-feasibility study that will provide inputs in developing a road map for capitalizing on 
innovative technologies and data sources for infrastructure quality monitoring. The findings will 
potentially help DMC transport agencies to reduce monitoring costs and enable them to identify 
the most effective preventive maintenance actions and contractual approaches. The TA team will 
carry out in-depth consultations with relevant government agencies to discuss concrete steps to 
ensure sustainability of this type of initiative. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Research  studies  and  capacity  building  on  urban  infrastructure 
development and management in developing Asia conducted. The TA will conduct data 
collection, economic research, and capacity building on issues related to urban infrastructure in 
developing Asia, especially but not limited to transport infrastructure.13 Candidate projects include

(i) conducting advance assessment of how roads, railways, ports, and/or airports in one selected 
Asian city will improve accessibility of residents and affect urban and economic structure in 
catchment areas in the long term; (ii) examining what policies are necessary to complement urban 
transport  infrastructure  in  one  or  two  selected  Asian  cities  to  maximize  the  benefits  of 
infrastructure (e.g., land-use regulations); (iii) assessing urban congestion of selected Asian cities 
(10 or fewer) and how ongoing transport infrastructure projects improve urban mobility; (iv) 
organizing a conference on urban infrastructure development and management to promote 
research and knowledge sharing on urban infrastructure in developing world; and (v) helping build 
local government capacity in urban utility regulation and management and supporting research 
on urban utility regulation such as tariff setting. All studies will require collecting or accessing 
innovative, geo-coded big data. The capacity building should involve how to use big data to 
regulate or manage utilities. 
 
12.  Output 3: Case studies on impacts of high-quality infrastructure conducted and 
disseminated.  The  TA  will  conduct  a few  case  studies  evaluating  the  impact  of  selected 
infrastructure projects, including transport infrastructure investments in selected GMS countries 
and  ADB’s  Integrated  Road  Investment  Program,  tranche  1  for  Sri  Lanka.14 These  cases 
represent  two  different  infrastructure  interventions:  a  region-wide  long-term  project  and  an 
innovative  rural  road  project.15 These  evaluation  studies  will  adopt  high-level  information 
technologies, such as satellite imagery and other big data, and identify a wide range of economic 
and social impacts. Lessons will provide insights for other ADB projects and support peer-learning 
opportunities for ADB’s members. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by the 
Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items 
are listed in Appendix 2. 
 
14.  The following are ineligible items under the JFPR: (i) purchase of vehicles, (ii) salaries for 
civil servants, (iii) foreign travel, (iv) scholarships or long internships, (v) detailed engineering 
design, (vi) civil works and other related expenses, and (vii) those under ADB’s List of Ineligible 
Items (or Negative List) and Prohibited Investment Activities List.16 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA. ERCD will be responsible for supervision and management of 
consultants, procurement, and accomplishment and evaluation of the outputs.17 For optimal 
coordination and synergy as “One ADB,” especially regarding capacity building, ERCD will 
coordinate and collaborate with ADB’s other departments and resident missions, as appropriate.18 
 
14 Target GMS countries include Cambodia, the Lao People’s Democratic Republic, Myanmar, Thailand, and Viet Nam. 
15 The specific projects in output 3 were identified based on the demand from regional departments, availability of data, 
and feasibility of the studies. 
16 Foreign travel is ineligible “except in the case of TA projects where participation of recipient countries, including civil 
servants, in international workshops, conferences, mentoring visits, or study tours is fully justified in the original 
proposal with detailed description, objectives and budget, and approved by the Government of Japan. Maximum 
amount for foreign travel is $0.1 million or 10% of the amount of the proposal, whichever is lower.” Refer to the Japan 
Fund for Poverty Reduction 2018 Policy Guidelines for Technical Assistance Grant. 
17 The TA team will have quarterly meetings to monitor and discuss progresses. 
18 The Transport Thematic Group has been consulted for the development of the TA. The findings and policy 
recommendations of the three outputs will be shared and discussed with government officials and ADB operations

capacity building in coordination with country authorities.

firms. Requisite fields of expertise and cost estimates of consulting services in the table are

departments at various platforms, including the Asia-Pacific Senior Roads Executive Program, which will be

Operations.

data platforms or modeling techniques and will be selected through either consultant qualification 
selection or direct contracting method. Because only a few firms have highly specialized expertise 
in developing machine learning algorithms and transport infrastructure quality monitoring and 
impact evaluation, the proposed selection methods are deemed justified. ADB will engage the 
consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its

18.  ADB’s procurement. The TA requires both macro and micro data. The datasets will be 
procured  from  government  agencies,  private  data  providers,  and  other  research  institutes. 
Equipment  (e.g.,  laptop  computers,  handheld  devices,  sensors,  and  other  infrastructure 
monitoring equipment) and software may also be procured for the TA where needed. Where 
applicable,  the  TA  team  will  coordinate  with  ADB’s  Procurement,  Portfolio,  and  Financial 
Management Department and Office of the General Counsel before purchasing datasets and 
signing data use agreements with DMC statistical agencies and third-party database providers. 
The  TA  team  will  also  consult  ADB’s  Information  Technology  Department  and  Office  of 
Administrative Services in relation to the purchase of information and communication technology 
hardware and software. All TA procurement will be in accordance with the ADB Procurement 
Policy and the associated staff instructions.20 When the TA is completed, the TA team will dispose 
of  any  procured  equipment  in  compliance  with  the  project  administration  instructions  on 
administering  grant-financed  TA  projects.21 Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in

time to time).  
 
19.  Social  media  and  websites.  Knowledge  product  dissemination  may  be  conducted 
through uploading of TA outputs in ADB or other websites or social media, such as Twitter and 
blogs. This will be coordinated closely with the Department of Communications and Information 
Technology Department.
